t: Habakkuk 1
The*p pronouncement that the prophet Habakkuk saw.
Habakkuk’s First Prayer
How*pn long, Lord,*s must I call for help and*ln you do not listen or*ln cry out to you about violence and*ln you do not save?
Why*ln do you force me to look at injustice? Why*ln do you tolerate wrongdoing? Oppression*ln and violence are right in front of me. Strife*ln is ongoing, and conflict escalates.
This*ln is why the law is ineffective and*ln justice never emerges. For*ln the wicked restrict the righteous; therefore,*ln justice comes out perverted.
God’s First Answer
Look*pn at the nations and observe— be*ln utterly astounded! For*ln I am doing something in your days that*ln you will not believe when*ln you hear about it.
Look!*ln I am raising up the Chaldeans, that*ln bitter, impetuous nation that*ln marches across the earth’s open spaces to*ln seize territories not its own.
They*ln are fierce and terrifying; their*ln views of justice and sovereignty stem*ln from themselves.

Their*ln horses are swifter than leopards and*ln more fierce than wolves of the night. Their*ln horsemen charge ahead; their*ln horsemen come from distant lands. They*ln fly like eagles, swooping to devour.
All*ln of them come to do violence; their*ln faces are set in determination. They*ln gather prisoners like sand.
They*ln mock kings, and*ln rulers are a joke to them. They*ln laugh at every fortress and*ln build siege ramps to capture it.
Then*ln they sweep by like the wind and*ln pass through. They*ln are guilty; their strength is their god.
Habakkuk’s Second Prayer
Are*pn you not from eternity, Lord*s my God? My*ln Holy One, you will not die. Lord,*sln you appointed them to execute judgment; my*ln Rock, you destined them to punish us.

Your*ln eyes are too pure to look on evil, and*ln you cannot tolerate wrongdoing. So*ln why do you tolerate those who are treacherous? Why*ln are you silent while*ln one who is wicked swallows up one*ln who is more righteous than himself?
You*ln have made mankind like*ln the fish of the sea, like*ln marine creatures that have no ruler.
The*ln Chaldeans pull them all up with a hook, catch*ln them in their dragnet, and*ln gather them in their fishing net; that*ln is why they are glad and rejoice.
That*ln is why they sacrifice to their dragnet and*ln burn incense to their fishing net, for*ln by these things their portion is rich and*ln their food plentiful.
Will*ln they therefore empty their net and*ln continually slaughter nations without mercy?
